title: RS22272
content: The Federal Election Campaign Act (FECA), amended by the Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act of 2002 (BCRA), regulates "federal election activity," including voter registration drives, voter identification, get-out-the-vote drives, and public communications that refer to a federal candidate. Public communications are defined as various forms of media communications to the general public. The Federal Election Campaign Act (FECA), amended by the Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act of 2002 (BCRA), regulates "federal election activity," including voter registration drives, voter identification, get-out-the-vote drives, and public communications that refer to a federal candidate. FECA defines "public communications" as various forms of media communications to the general public, such as broadcast, cable, satellite, newspaper, magazine, outdoor advertising facility, mass mailing, or telephone bank communications. Regulated federal funds, also known as "hard money," are subject to FECA's contribution limitations, source restrictions, and reporting requirements. The FEC exempted Internet communications from federal campaign finance regulation by excluding them from the definition of "public." In response to BCRA amendments in 2002, FEC exempted Internet communications from federal campaign finance regulation. BCRA sponsors sued FEC, arguing that this exemption could lead to circumvention of campaign finance laws. In 2004, the U.S. District Court agreed with the sponsors and overturned FEC's regulations. In 2004, the U.S. District Court overturned FEC's regulations on Internet communications, agreeing with BCRA sponsors that the exemption could lead to circumvention of campaign finance laws. The court found that excluding Internet communications from the definition of "public communication" was inconsistent with Congress's intent in enacting BCRA. The U.S. District Court overturned FEC's regulations on Internet communications in 2004, disagreeing with Congress's use of the phrase "or any other form of general public political advertising" in the BCRA definition of "public communication." The court found that the FEC failed to provide legislative history to justify ignoring the statute's plain meaning. The court upheld the definition of "generic campaign activity" as a "public communication" but criticized the FEC's 2002 NPRM for lacking adequate notice to the public under the APA. The court overturned FEC regulations on Internet communications in 2004, finding that the FEC failed to provide adequate notice to the public under the APA. The court also ruled that Internet communications exempted from the definition of "public communications" could not be considered "coordinated communications" subject to FECA regulation. The court overturned FEC regulations on Internet communications in 2004, ruling that they could not be considered "coordinated communications" subject to FECA regulation. The court remanded the case to the FEC for further action consistent with its decision. In response, the FEC published an NPRM seeking comment on amending the definition of "public communication" to conform to the ruling. The court remanded the case to the FEC for further action consistent with its decision. In response, the FEC published an NPRM seeking comment on amending the definition of "public communication" to include paid Internet advertisements. The general exemption from FECA coverage of news stories, commentaries, and editorials distributed online also applies to communications over the Internet by uncompensated individuals or groups influencing federal elections. H.R. 1606, the Online Freedom of Speech Act, failed to receive the necessary votes for passage. Additionally, H.R. 4194 aimed to exclude Internet communications from FECA regulation but regulate communications placed on a website for a fee. In response to concerns about the Online Freedom of Speech Act potentially allowing FECA circumvention, two bills were proposed in the 109th Congress: H.R. 4194 (Shays-Meehan) aimed to exclude Internet communications from FECA regulation, while H.R. 4900 (Allen-Bass) would have exempted most individual online communications from regulation.
